title: Ticket #6072: condor_status fails inside Docker container
description:
When running a personal HTCondor inside a Docker container using default networking, the following fails: 

condor_status -schedd `hostname`

It appears this is because get_daemon_name fails to behave reasonably for hosts without a FQDN. Docker sets the hostname to a randomly generated string, such as eb4f00c8f1ca. Docker correctly sets up forward and reverse host<->IP resolution using /etc/hosts. However, both hostname and hostname -f (which returns the FQDN) returns eb4f00c8f1ca. Unfortunately, get_fqdn_from_hostname considers any FQDN without a period (. character) invalid and returns the empty string. Then, get_daemon_name will happily return the empty string to the caller. Finally, condor_status errors out when the daemon name to query is the empty string.

I believe get_daemon_name or get_fqdn_from_hostname should be updated to simply pass through hostnames where there is no registered DNS name.

I only see two uses of get_fqdn_from_hostname in the code base, meaning it might not be so bad to change semantics. The other user is build_valid_daemon_name (which has some really unfortunate semantics - allocates memory via new[], meaning it must be disposed of via delete[]. Over half the call sites I examined for build_valid_daemon_name do this incorrectly).
remarks:
2016-Dec-30 15:29:04 by gthain:
Note that you can specify the hostname of the docker container in the all-singing docker run command line.

2016-Dec-30 15:33:40 by tlmiller:
I'll take a look at purging the new[], since that's evil. I'll have to think about the right thing to do for get_fqdn_from_hostname; since we claim to work without DNS, if we don't have an FQDN, we should probably just see if the hostname roundtrips in the resolver. It's also probably the case that get_daemon_name should never return an empty string; that doesn't seem likely to be useful, but I'll have to check what's going on.

2017-Jan-03 16:50:37 by tlmiller:
I'm looking at a fix for this, but until then, it seems to work to set the name of the Docker container to something including a '.'.
